title-group.article-title: In Vivo Optical Tissue Differentiation by Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy
title-group.subtitle: Preliminary Results for Tissue-Specific Laser Surgery

author-notes.corresp: Florian Stelzle, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Friedrich-Alexander-University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, Glückstrasse 11, 91054 Erlangen, Germany Email: Florian.Stelzle@uk-erlangen.de

abstract.p: Objectives. Laser surgery requires feedback to avoid the accidental destruction of critically important tissues. It was the aim of the authors to identify different tissue types in vivo by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy to set the basis for tissue-specific control of laser surgery. Methods. Tissue differentiation was performed on in vivo tissue of rats (skin, fat, muscle, and nerve) by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy between 350 and 650 nm. Data analysis was done using principal components analysis, followed by linear discriminant analysis (LDA). The differentiation performance was evaluated by receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis. Results. ROC analysis showed a tissue differentiation of 100%, with a high sensitivity of more than 99%. Only the tissue pair skin/fat showed a reduced differentiation performance and specificity. Conclusion. The results show the general viability of in vivo optical tissue differentiation and create a basis for the further development of a control system for tissue-specific laser surgery.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laser surgery provides the advantages of high precision and sterility, combined with little trauma.1-3 However, these advantages are accompanied by a lack of haptic feedback during the tissue cutting because the laser ablation is remote. If there is no information about the exact depth of laser tissue ablation or the type of tissue ablated at the bottom of the cut, laser surgery comes with the inherent risk of an accidental destruction of critically important organs and tissues, such as blood vessel walls or nerves.4-6 A technical feedback system may assist and control tissue-specific laser ablation if it is able to identify the type of biological tissue targeted to be either laser ablated or preserved during surgery. The ideal laser ablation feedback and particularly tissue differentiation system should be remote and fast enough to provide tissue identification in real time. Such a feedback system is expected to function in a loop, warning about the results after nearly every laser pulse. Based on the obtained data, the feedback system operates a real-time process control that stops the laser ablation when it reaches the next tissue layer or an anatomical structure that is to be preserved (eg, nerves).

A few approaches for tissue differentiation during laser surgery have been developed so far, including laser Doppler anemometry,1 confocal microscopy,3 optical coherence tomography (OCT),3 and fluorescence spectroscopy.1,5 The interaction between laser radiation and biological tissue leads to optical and acoustical process emissions, which have also been used for tissue differentiation.7-10 However, these methods are either not remote, such as acoustics methods, or not fast enough, such as optical coherence tomography, LDA, and confocal microscopy. Fluorescence emission parameters seem to be altered under laser ablation conditions.6 The emission methods may also hardly be usable under conditions with a relatively high intensity of stray light, as during open laser surgery.

Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy provides a straightforward and low resource-consuming approach to optical tissue differentiation that can be exploited remotely and is easily integrated into the hand piece of the laser scalpel. This is a real-time method because the integration time of the signal collection can be as short as a fraction of a microsecond. The stray light can be taken into account if it is consistent. The applied light is absorbed or scattered, depending on the optical properties of the type of tissue. The optical properties of several types of normal tissue have been analyzed in animals and humans ex vivo11-13 and in vivo.14 Diffuse reflectance spectra for certain types of tissues are well known (eg, ex vivo: fatty tissue, bladder, brain, heart, kidney, liver, lung, muscle, skin, uterus, and vessels; in vivo: brain, muscle, and liver).15 To investigate the prospects of this technique for diagnostics, premalignant and malignant tissues have been successfully differentiated from normal/benign tissue by analyzing diffuse reflectance spectra.16-18 Similar results were found for the differentiation between pathologically altered versus regular cardiovascular tissue.19,20 Diffuse reflectance has been successfully applied in tissue differentiation ex vivo.21,22 However, there is still a lack of information concerning the differentiation of regular/normal types of tissue under in vivo conditions by means of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. Thus, the aim of this study was to investigate whether diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, in combination with principal components analysis (PCA) and linear discriminant analysis (LDA), can differentiate between regular types of tissue in vivo to create a technological basis for a remote optical feedback system for tissue-specific laser surgery. The study placed special emphasis on the identification of nervous tissue because the preservation of these anatomical structures is crucial in any surgical intervention.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: For the experiments, we used 3 female rats (stock: Wistar; breeder: Charles-River, Sandhofer Weg 7, 97633 Sulzfeld, Germany), 6 to 12 months of age and weighing between 700 to 800 g. For general anesthesia, we used an intraperitoneal injection with 75 mg/kg ketamine hydrochloride (Ketavet) and 10 mg/kg Xylazine (Rompun), individually adapted to the body weight of each animal.

After the animals were completely anesthetized, we shaved and disinfected the right lower limb. The following operative techniques were performed under strict aseptic conditions. The tissue of interest was dissected using scalpels. During the surgical tissue dissection, care was taken not to hamper the proper blood perfusion of the tissues of interest. Superficial hemostasis was achieved with the localized electrocauterization of blood vessels during the dissection procedure.

In all, 4 types of tissue were dissected on the lower limb of each animal: skin, subcutaneous fat, muscle, and nerve. For nerve tissue, we used the complete bundle of the ischiatic nerve, which had a diameter of 1 mm on average.

After the tissue was dissected, the surface, except for the skin area, was carefully moistened with a sterile saline solution to prevent the tissue from drying out. Subsequently, the optical measurements were performed on the 4 tissue types of each animal. Anesthesia, tissue dissection, and the experiments took 60 minutes per animal. After performing the optical measurements, we killed the animals humanely under continuous anesthesia by means of an intraperitoneal injection of Brevimythal.
The animals had no local or systemic illness to cause any pathological tissue alteration prior to the optical tissue measurements.
The in vivo animal experiments were authorized by the government of Mittelfranken, Germany (Approval Number: 54-2532.1-21/08; approval date: 25.11.2008).

sec.title: Optical Measurements
sec.p: In the remote setup, light was irradiated onto the in vivo tissue via a pulsed Xenon lamp PX-2 (Ocean Optics, USA), and diffuse reflectance spectra were measured using a reflection/backscattering probe QR600-7-SR-125F (Ocean Optics, USA). A high-resolution spectrometer HR4000 (Ocean Optics, USA) with a 1.1-nm optical resolution and a dynamic range of 25 dB S/N and 31 dB was used for detection. The spectrometer’s accuracy is greater than 99%. Within 10 ms of integration time, the reflection/backscattering probe acquired the diffuse reflectance spectra by means of a single collection fiber surrounded by 6 illumination fibers. Each optical fiber has a 600 µm core diameter and a 0.22 numerical aperture.

For the measurements, animals were placed under the setup, with the dissected tissue surfaces at a standardized distance of 1 cm from the distal end of the probe (Figure 1). Care was taken to place the animals in a way that the surface of the tissue to be measured provided an angle of 90° toward the beam of the illumination light and hence parallel to the surface of the spectrometer probe. This protocol was used for an exact standardization of the measurements. However, distance and angulation of the probe are not meant to be critical parameters for the method. The applied light is diffusely reflected in all directions and distance will mainly influence signal strength. For the differentiation analysis, we concentrated on spectral shape characteristics, which are known to be basically determined by tissue parameters.

caption.p: Setup for the measurements of diffuse reflectance spectra on in vivo animal tissue

sec.p: The measurements were done under constant conditions of minimized environmental stray light in the laboratory, which allowed us to exploit the experimental setup. We took care not to perform the optical measurements on tissue surfaces that were altered by the dissection or the electrocauterization, to prevent an alteration of the measurement results through these artifacts.

For each tissue sample from each animal, 6 different spots were chosen at a distance of 0.5 cm from each other, and 30 diffuse reflectance spectra were acquired per spot (180 spectra per tissue sample). In total, 600 diffuse reflectance spectra were acquired for each of the 4 types of tissues investigated.

sec.title: Data Processing
sec.p: We converted the raw signal S Rd(λ) from the diffuse reflectance spectra into diffuse reflectance Rd(λ). By means of the reflectance standard WS-1 (250-1500 nm, Ocean Optics, USA), we collected spectra and measured the light source emission spectrum S R(λ). The background signal SD(λ) was subtracted from the raw signal SRd(λ) and subsequently divided by the light source emission spectrum reference SR(λ) less the background signal SD(λ). The diffuse reflectance was calculated by multiplying the result by 100%.

We used the wavelength range from 350 to 650 nm because this has been proved to be the optimal wavelength range for tissue differentiation by means of diffuse reflectance under ex vivo conditions.21 After preprocessing, the spectra consisted of 1151 data points within the 350 to 650 nm range (0.26 nm wavelength resolution—exact wavelength range from 349.88 to 649.98 nm). The background signal SD(λ) was used to correct for stray light during the measurement.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: We reduced the dimensionality of the data set by systematically transforming the predictor variables into a smaller number of derived variables by means of a PCA of the standardized and scaled reflectance data (mean value 0 and standard deviation 1).23 The primary analysis was based on 10 PCAs (PCA 1 to 10), which were subsequently reduced to 7 PCAs while still covering the majority of the variation in the data set. Membership to a specific class label—that is, the 4 different probabilities of each observation to belong to each of the 4 tissues—was estimated by means of multiclass LDA.23

Using 1 single animal subject from the original sample as the validation data point and the remaining subjects as training data points, we performed a leave-one-out cross-validation.24 Each training set was created by taking all the samples except one, the validation set being the sample left out. Subsequently, for 1 sample, we had 2 different training sets and 1 different validation set, each. These sets consisted of 1800 diffuse reflectance spectra taken from 4 tissue types. Divided among the 3 rat subjects, each subset holds 600 observations of 1 single rat. Class membership probabilities of all observations of 1 rat were calculated by PCA and LDA, trained with the observations of the remaining 2 rats (1200 observations). By repeating the calculations, we computed the predictions for all observations in the data set. Hence the obtained data were analyzed by means of receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis25 using pairwise comparisons of all tissues. We calculated sensitivities and specificities for the optimal cut point maximizing the Youden index26 and areas under the ROC curve (AUC) using the class probabilities obtained by LDA.
Statistics were computed using the freely available programming language R.27

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Spectra of diffuse reflectance Rd(λ) were processed from the raw diffuse reflectance spectra SRd(λ) (Figure 2) and centered/scaled, using a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1 (Figure 3). The variation of the data set was covered in the 10 PCs in Table 1, and 7 of them already accounted for 100% of the diffuse reflectance variances under the conditions of this study (Table 2). Hence, these were consequentially chosen in all subsequent cross-validating steps. PC1 represented 95% to 98% of the variance, whereas PC2 is only responsible for 2% to 3% of the variances of the diffuse reflectance spectra. The rest of the PCs (PCs 3-10) together covered 1% or less of the variance but still contributed significantly. ROC analysis showed that tissue differentiation by means of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy worked very well under in vivo conditions for all tissue types investigated in this study, except for the pair skin/fat, which showed only reduced differentiation results (Table 3, Figures 4 and 5). The sensitivity was equally high for all tissue pairs (Table 4). However, the specificity was again reduced for the tissue pair skin/fat, mirroring the AUC results (Table 5).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: When light is incident on tissue, a typical multiple elastic scattering occurs, resulting in partial absorption of the fractioned light spectra. On the cellular and subcellular levels, this scattering is mainly caused by inhomogeneities, such as particles ranging from proteins to cell organelles to the cell itself. Biochemical and morphological properties in particular, such as cell quantity, chromatin to cytoplasm ratio, nuclear texture, mitochondria, vascularity, and the characteristics of the extracellular matrix, are known to contribute to the scattering.25-29

The scattered and diffusely reflected light can be measured by illuminating the tissue with continuous-wave white light and recapturing the reflected radiation using optical diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. Especially in the oral and maxillofacial region, tissue distinction in laser ablation processing turns out to be a crucial step toward the establishment of controlled laser surgery. In this complex area, the preservation of neural structures is essential because a laser is capable of impairing nerve function through overheating processes or the direct ablation of neural tissue.30-32

The general use of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy in biotissue differentiation was recently shown on soft and hard tissue samples while performing ex vivo experiments on animal tissue.22,33 However, there is a lack of information about the effect of blood and perfusion on optical tissue differentiation when using diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.

To approach this issue, mean diffuse reflectance spectral analysis was performed in vivo on 4 different types of tissue—muscle, nerve, skin, fat—which were dissected in the lower limbs of 3 female rats. Analogous to our prior studies, where we were able to prove the viability of diffuse reflectance spectra for ex vivo21,22 tissue differentiation, we computed a PCA. Our preliminary statistical analysis found 10 PCs with relevant variance contributions that were capable of tissue differentiation.

Calculation and matching of each PC takes a certain amount of computing power, and therefore processing time, which will represent a crucial factor in further implementing this technique in a real-time closed-loop control system. Hence there is a need for minimizing the computational processing time to implement a real-time analysis of the current tissue structure for each laser ablation pulse. We therefore restricted the PCs to a minimum amount, with as little influence as possible on the tissue discrimination capacity. On further analysis, we found that 7 PCs completely covered 100% of the variance of the diffuse reflectance spectra under the conditions of this study, and consequently, we chose them in all subsequent cross-validating steps. However, an exact measurement of the computational time needed for tissue differentiation was not the goal of this study. This issue has to be investigated in further studies before the technique can be implemented into a laser control feedback system.

As mentioned above, prior studies from our workgroup yielded promising results in differentiating tissue ex vivo.21,22 However, the effect of the blood supply while distinguishing between different tissues by means of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy has not been taken into account so far. Blood, for example hemoglobin, is known to be a major absorber in the visible spectra and can be found in its oxygenated and deoxygenated form. On ex vivo tissue, it has been shown that the reflectance decreases because of increasing deoxygenation and loss of hemoglobin,34,35 followed by a gradual decrease of scattering and absorption over time in the visible spectral range during the first 24 hours postmortem.35 Hence in this study, we transferred our findings to an in vivo rat model to take into account the effect of microcirculation on optical tissue differentiation. The blood flow, for example, microcirculation of the prepared tissue samples, was maintained during the optical measurement procedure to prevent an alteration of the reflectance spectra through deoxygenation or the loss of blood cells in the analyzed tissue spectra.

Regarding the absorption spectra of oxyhemoglobin and deoxyhemoglobin, a similarity with the data extracted from PC2 can be found. Consequently, it is assumed that PC2, with its peaks at 410, 540, and 580 nm, represents the occurrence of blood in this data set. A homogeneous contribution of PC1 was shown within the analyzed wavelength rate, representing the biomorphological structures other than blood.36 It is remarkable that the blood-specific PC2 only comprised a minor amount of the diffuse reflectance spectra variances. With PC1 covering more than 95%, we conclude that even though a certain amount of influence is a result of the presence of PC2, for example hemoglobin, the major differentiation potential stems from PC1 variances and, therefore, tissue specific biomorphological properties.

ROC curves were constructed by computing the sensitivity and specificity of tissue differentiation. Subsequent computing of AUC, which measures the discrimination ability of tissue by means of diffuse reflectance measurements, affirmed the results of prior ex vivo studies by our group. For the present in vivo model, an equally high discrimination performance, sensitivity, and specificity in all tissue pairs could be shown. However, the tissue pair skin/fat only reached a reduced discrimination performance of 75% and a specificity of 70% in contrast to the other tissue pairs that each scored 100%. In our prior ex vivo study, no lack of discrimination within the tissue pair skin/fat could be observed.21 In that prior study, we used ex vivo pig models to carry out the measurements. The thickness of pig skin, including the epidermis and dermis, varies in a range of 2.58 to 3.43 mm and shows many similarities to human skin on the histological level.37 In our current study, we resorted to an in vivo rat model, which provides different dermal and epidermal thickness parameters. The thickness of rat skin is around 0.86 mm, which is thinner than the dermal layer of pigs.38 Furthermore, the outer stratum corneum layer in rats is thin, and the keratinocytes are relatively disseminated compared with pig skin, which inhibits closely packed keratinocytes, serving as an intense light scattering and absorbing element.38 Furthermore, short-wave visible light penetrates biotissue like pig or rat skin up to 0.5 to 2.5 mm.39 Hence regarding the skin thickness of rats and the depth of light penetration in it, we assume that penetration and subsequent scattering of light also took place in the subdermal area, which is known to comprise large amounts of fatty tissue. Hence, the low differentiation results for the tissue pair skin/fat may be a result of the biological similarity of the tissues, taking into account the complete interrogation volume. With these considerations, we expect an increase in the differentiation performance and specificity of skin and subcutaneous fat tissue when transferring our study design to an animal model with thicker skin layers or to human tissue. However, further in vivo studies have to be performed to investigate this issue.

In a prior in vitro study carried out by our work group, the tissue pair nerve/fat demonstrated a decline of sensitivity (93%) and specificity (91%). It was assumed that the biological similarities of these structures contribute to their impaired optical differentiation. Fatty tissue is known to comprise large amounts of lipids like triglycerides, cholesterol, and fatty acids. The histology of nerve fibers, used in both the studies, shows a myelin sheath that contains more than 75% lipids, covering large areas of the actual nerve fiber.40 With blood being one major absorber and reflector,41 we concluded that the blood flow under in vivo conditions may modify the diffuse reflectance spectra.42 The microcirculation of blood presents itself differently in fat and nervous tissue. Blood supply is crucial in nervous tissue. Lack of nutrients, like glycogen, or hypoxia in nerve cells induces cell degeneration and a rapidly progressing loss of function.43 Therefore, a dense network of vessels is necessary for maintaining the normal energy metabolism of nerve cells in vivo. In contrast, fatty tissue consists of capacious energy storage cells with a relatively low metabolic rate. It consists mainly of loosely associated lipid-filled cells within a framework of collagen fibers. About 60% to 85% of the weight of adipose tissue is lipid. The remaining weight of white adipose tissue is composed of water (5%-30%) and protein (2%-3%). Metabolism only takes place in the marginal area of the cell surrounding the lipid storage area.44 Subsequently, lower cell density and hence lower vascularization can be found in fatty tissue, as compared with neural tissue. These tissue-specific blood flow levels under in vivo conditions are assumed to significantly enhance the discrimination ability and refine in vitro results.29,45 This hypothesis supports the results of our study. We achieved a sensitivity and specificity of 100% for the tissue pair nerve/fat. Hence, the diffuse reflectance spectra discrimination proved to be a valid method for differentiating this highly relevant tissue pair under in vivo conditions.

Compression of tissue is known to alter the optical properties of biological tissues.46 Furthermore, the clinical application of a laser in combination with a spectrometer in direct contact with tissue can cause the spreading of ablated tissue.47-49 By using a remote setup, these factors could be eliminated. The influence of surrounding stray light was minimized by increasing the signal-to-noise ratio mathematically.50 This technique worked well for a laboratory setting, but the illumination by an operational lamp may influence the diffuse reflectance spectra during surgery. To solve this probable interference, the spectrum, coming from the operational lamp, has to be recorded and could be mathematically extracted from the reflectance spectra. Alternatively, the illuminating light source from the optical setup may be used to illuminate the region of surgical interest, replacing the operative lamp. However, the impact of this factor has to be investigated in further studies before transferring the technique to the operation room.

When performing laser surgery, high amounts of energy are deposited in the tissue, causing ablation with process emissions, for example, smoke, combustion plume, or plasma, dependent on the applied energy parameters. Additionally, laser-related photochemicals and thermal and nonlinear processes will cause tissue alterations, such as exsiccation, carbonization, or even charring, which may change the optical properties of tissue. Process emissions can be avoided by acquiring the diffuse reflectance spectra during the laser pulse pauses when using a pulsed laser system for tissue ablation. Gauging the impact of laser-induced tissue alterations on optical tissue differentiation is a crucial step toward an application of a closed-loop control for laser surgery and has to be investigated in further studies.

Even though interspecies differences must be considered when transferring the results to human tissue, this study shows the general potential of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy with regard to implementing this technology into a feedback control system. However, this preliminary study was performed on a limited group of animals. Further studies are necessary before these results can be transferred to a prototype laser surgery control system for application on human beings.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: ROC analysis showed that all tissue types, except for the pair skin/fat, could be differentiated very well in all cases by means of diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, followed by PCA and LDA. The sensitivity was equally high for all tissue pairs; however, the specificity was again reduced for the tissue pair skin/fat, which is assumed to be caused by the thin cutis layer of the animal model used in this study. However, the results of this study have shown the general viability of in vivo tissue differentiation by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. In vivo conditions, for example blood perfusion, contribute to the accuracy of optical identification of nervous tissue, which is a crucial factor in the implementation of this tissue differentiation technique in a closed-loop system for laser surgery, with the goal of a lower complication rate and greater safety for the patients.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge funding from the ELAN-Funds, University of Erlangen-Nuremberg, DFG-German Research Foundation, and the Erlangen Graduate School in Advanced Optical Technologies (SAOT) by the German National Science Foundation (DFG) as part of the Excellence Initiative.
